elements.content: Metal-radical alternating chains [Co(hfac)2HNN] n crystallized in two morphs containing repeating all-cis (α) and cis,cis,trans (β) configurations with respect to the OHNN−Co−OHNN geometry (HNN = 4,4,5,5-tetramethylimidazolin-1-oxyl 3-oxide). Both phases showed magnetization jumps with hysteresis at 2 K. The α phase has a relatively high activation energy of magnetization reorientation (193 K).
elements.clean_text: Metal-radical alternating chains [Co(hfac)2HNN] n  crystallized in two morphs containing repeating all-cis (α) and cis,cis,trans (β) configurations with respect to the OHNN-Co-OHNN geometry (HNN = 4,4,5,5-tetramethylimidazolin-1-oxyl 3-oxide). Both phases showed magnetization jumps with hysteresis at 2 K. The α phase has a relatively high activation energy of magnetization reorientation (193 K).

elements.content: We applied hydro nitronyl nitroxide (HNN) as a minimal radical bridge to metal-radical magnetic solids. X-ray crystallographic analysis on [Co(hfac)2HNN] n revealed that there were two morphs of metal-radical alternating chain structures containing repeating all-cis (α) and cis,cis,trans (β) configurations with respect to the OHNN−Co−OHNN geometry. Both phases showed magnetization jumps with hysteresis at 2 K. The α phase has a relatively high activation energy of magnetization reorientation (193 K).
elements.clean_text: We applied hydro nitronyl nitroxide (HNN) as a minimal radical bridge to metal-radical magnetic solids. X-ray crystallographic analysis on [Co(hfac)2HNN] n  revealed that there were two morphs of metal-radical alternating chain structures containing repeating all-cis (α) and cis,cis,trans (β) configurations with respect to the OHNN-Co-OHNN geometry. Both phases showed magnetization jumps with hysteresis at 2 K. The α phase has a relatively high activation energy of magnetization reorientation (193 K).

elements.content: There have been ample examples of alternating one-dimensional (1D) complexes containing nitronyl and imino nitroxide radicals (Chart a) with metal hfac salts in pursuit of metal-radical hybrid magnets (hfac stands for 1,1,1,5,5,5-hexafluoropentane-2,4-dionate). We assume that the choice of small ligands and anions is crucial in order to bestow strong exchange interaction, and accordingly high T c, on bulk magnetic materials. Actually, we have developed the minimal bridges HNN and HIN for strongly coupled systems, [MnII(hfac)2L] n (L = HNN, HIN). On the other hand, Gatteschi et al. reported the single-chain magnets (SCMs) using somewhat bulky NN bridges such as [CoII(hfac)2(p-methoxyphenyl-NN)] n (1) and [DyIII(hfac)3(p-phenoxyphenyl-NN)] n . Slow magnetic relaxation in SCMs requires the condition that the ratio of the intrachain interaction over the interchain interaction must be high. The short HNN bridge might satisfy the requirement of larger intrachain interactions, whereas bulky RNN bridges were supposed to be suitable for smaller interchain interactions. To clarify whether the former requirement outweighs the latter, we investigated the magnetic properties of [CoII(hfac)2HNN] n (2). A few examples of CoII-based SCMs are known so far.
elements.clean_text: There have been ample examples of alternating one-dimensional (1D) complexes containing nitronyl and imino nitroxide radicals (Chart a) with metal hfac salts in pursuit of metal-radical hybrid magnets (hfac stands for 1,1,1,5,5,5-hexafluoropentane-2,4-dionate). We assume that the choice of small ligands and anions is crucial in order to bestow strong exchange interaction, and accordingly high T c, on bulk magnetic materials. Actually, we have developed the minimal bridges HNN and HIN for strongly coupled systems, [MnII(hfac)2L] n  (L = HNN, HIN). On the other hand, Gatteschi et al. reported the single-chain magnets (SCMs) using somewhat bulky NN bridges such as [CoII(hfac)2(p-methoxyphenyl-NN)] n  (1) and [DyIII(hfac)3(p-phenoxyphenyl-NN)] n . Slow magnetic relaxation in SCMs requires the condition that the ratio of the intrachain interaction over the interchain interaction must be high. The short HNN bridge might satisfy the requirement of larger intrachain interactions, whereas bulky RNN bridges were supposed to be suitable for smaller interchain interactions. To clarify whether the former requirement outweighs the latter, we investigated the magnetic properties of [CoII(hfac)2HNN] n  (2). A few examples of CoII-based SCMs are known so far.

elements.content: Structural Formulas
elements.clean_text: 1  Structural Formulas

elements.content: Complexation of Co(hfac)2 with HNN was conducted according to the method reported for the MnII analogue, giving two phases of 2. Platelet crystals (α phase) were preferentially obtained from heptane−ether, while needlelike crystals (β phase) were obtained from ether−dichloromethane, but they did not contain solvate molecules. Each phase was separately prepared, and the crystal structure and magnetic properties were investigated.
elements.clean_text: Complexation of Co(hfac)2 with HNN was conducted according to the method reported for the MnII analogue, giving two phases of 2. Platelet crystals (α phase) were preferentially obtained from heptane-ether, while needlelike crystals (β phase) were obtained from ether-dichloromethane, but they did not contain solvate molecules. Each phase was separately prepared, and the crystal structure and magnetic properties were investigated.

elements.content: Figure a shows a chain structure of α-2 determined in a monoclinic P21/c space group. A pair of HNN and Co(hfac)2 is a crystallographically independent unit. Each Co ion is hexacoordinated by four O atoms of two hfac moieties and by two O atoms of two different HNN radicals. The bond lengths of Co−OHNN are 2.084(3) and 2.083(3) Å. Two HNN O atoms are coordinated in a cis configuration with an OHNN−Co−OHNN angle of 88.4(1)°. The chain runs along the crystallographic b axis.
elements.clean_text: Figure a shows a chain structure of α-2 determined in a monoclinic P21/c space group. A pair of HNN and Co(hfac)2 is a crystallographically independent unit. Each Co ion is hexacoordinated by four O atoms of two hfac moieties and by two O atoms of two different HNN radicals. The bond lengths of Co-OHNN are 2.084(3) and 2.083(3) Å. Two HNN O atoms are coordinated in a cis configuration with an OHNN-Co-OHNN angle of 88.4(1)°. The chain runs along the crystallographic b axis.

elements.content: ORTEP drawings of four repeating units in the infinite chains of (a) α-2 and (b) β-2. The thermal ellipsoids are drawn at the 50% probability level. H atoms are omitted.
elements.clean_text: 1  ORTEP drawings of four repeating units in the infinite chains of (a) α-2 and (b) β-2. The thermal ellipsoids are drawn at the 50% probability level. H atoms are omitted.

elements.content: Another phase β-2 has a monoclinic C2/c space group. The crystallographically independent unit corresponds to one and a half formula units (Figure b). An inversion center resides at Co2, and accordingly two HNN O atoms are coordinated to Co2 in a trans manner, giving a cis,cis,trans configuration as a repeating unit. The cis OHNN−Co−OHNN angle is 90.7(1)°. The OHNN−Co bond lengths are 2.059(4)−2.083(4) Å. The chains are located parallel to the crystallographic a−c diagonal direction.
elements.clean_text: Another phase β-2 has a monoclinic C2/c space group. The crystallographically independent unit corresponds to one and a half formula units (Figure b). An inversion center resides at Co2, and accordingly two HNN O atoms are coordinated to Co2 in a trans manner, giving a cis,cis,trans configuration as a repeating unit. The cis OHNN-Co-OHNN angle is 90.7(1)°. The OHNN-Co bond lengths are 2.059(4)-2.083(4) Å. The chains are located parallel to the crystallographic a-c diagonal direction.

elements.content: The intrachain Co−Co distances are 6.8677(8) Å for α-2 and 6.4408(8) and 6.616(1) Å for β-2, which are much shorter than that of 1 (7.82 Å). Owing mainly to different M−O bond lengths, they are slightly shorter than the intrachain Mn−Mn distances (7.08 and 7.19 Å) in [Mn(hfac)2(HNN)] n (3). The shortest interchain Co−Co distances are 9.0448(9) and 9.428(1) Å for α- and β-2, respectively, which are also much shorter than that of 1 (11.29 Å). Complex 3 has a different packing motif, and the corresponding distance is reported to be 8.35 Å.
elements.clean_text: The intrachain Co-Co distances are 6.8677(8) Å for α-2 and 6.4408(8) and 6.616(1) Å for β-2, which are much shorter than that of 1 (7.82 Å). Owing mainly to different M-O bond lengths, they are slightly shorter than the intrachain Mn-Mn distances (7.08 and 7.19 Å) in [Mn(hfac)2(HNN)] n  (3). The shortest interchain Co-Co distances are 9.0448(9) and 9.428(1) Å for α- and β-2, respectively, which are also much shorter than that of 1 (11.29 Å). Complex 3 has a different packing motif, and the corresponding distance is reported to be 8.35 Å.

elements.content: Magnetic properties of randomly oriented polycrystalline samples were measured on a SQUID magnetometer. The temperature dependence of χm T measured at 500 Oe for both phases showed upsurge on cooling like the Mn analogue. The magnetization saturation values are ca. 1.3 × 104 erg Oe-1 mol-1 at 2 K for both phases, which corresponds to S total = 1 with g ave = 2.3 for the formula unit. These findings indicate that the chains are ferrimagnetic. Because the octahedral CoII ion has a d electron configuration of (t2g)5(eg)2, orbital overlaps between the magnetic orbitals of Co dπ(t2g) and HNN π* should be appreciable, giving rise to antiferromagnetic coupling. The plots of χm T vs T and anisotropic magnetization (M ||chain and M ⊥ chain) vs T for each phase are given in Figures S and 2S in the Supporting Information, respectively.
elements.clean_text: Magnetic properties of randomly oriented polycrystalline samples were measured on a SQUID magnetometer. The temperature dependence of χm T measured at 500 Oe for both phases showed upsurge on cooling like the Mn analogue. The magnetization saturation values are ca. 1.3 × 104 erg Oe-1 mol-1 at 2 K for both phases, which corresponds to S total = 1 with g ave = 2.3 for the formula unit. These findings indicate that the chains are ferrimagnetic. Because the octahedral CoII ion has a d electron configuration of (t2g)5(eg)2, orbital overlaps between the magnetic orbitals of Co dπ(t2g) and HNN π* should be appreciable, giving rise to antiferromagnetic coupling. The plots of χm T vs T and anisotropic magnetization (M ||chain and M ⊥ chain) vs T for each phase are given in Figures S and 2S in the Supporting Information, respectively.

elements.content: Single-crystal magnetic studies for both phases exhibited a remarkable Ising-type anisotropy in the chain direction. Hereafter magnetic properties were measured on a single crystal or aligned single crystals with a magnetic field applied parallel to the chain direction.
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal magnetic studies for both phases exhibited a remarkable Ising-type anisotropy in the chain direction. Hereafter magnetic properties were measured on a single crystal or aligned single crystals with a magnetic field applied parallel to the chain direction.

elements.content: Figure a shows the results of FCM (field-cooled magnetization), RM (remnant magnetization), and ZFCM (zero-field-cooled magnetization) on α-2. The ZFCM curve approached the FCM one, and the RM decreased on heating. Note that these profiles depended on the temperature scan rate. The results on β-2 (Figure b) showed the complete absence of RM and coincidence between ZFCM and FCM, indicating a much faster relaxation than that of α-2 and also than the time scale of the measurements (several minutes for each data point). Actually, we could observe the remnance of β-2 below 3 K as shown below.
elements.clean_text: Figure a shows the results of FCM (field-cooled magnetization), RM (remnant magnetization), and ZFCM (zero-field-cooled magnetization) on α-2. The ZFCM curve approached the FCM one, and the RM decreased on heating. Note that these profiles depended on the temperature scan rate. The results on β-2 (Figure b) showed the complete absence of RM and coincidence between ZFCM and FCM, indicating a much faster relaxation than that of α-2 and also than the time scale of the measurements (several minutes for each data point). Actually, we could observe the remnance of β-2 below 3 K as shown below.

elements.content: FCM, RM, and ZFCM for (a) α- and (b) β-2 in a temperature range of 5−50 K. A single crystal was used in each experiment. Applied fields were 5 and 30 Oe for α- and β-2, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 2  FCM, RM, and ZFCM for (a) α- and (b) β-2 in a temperature range of 5-50 K. A single crystal was used in each experiment. Applied fields were 5 and 30 Oe for α- and β-2, respectively.

elements.content: To clarify the relaxation behavior, we measured the frequency dependence of χac‘ and χac‘ ‘, which represent in-phase and out-of-phase parts, respectively, of ac magnetic susceptibility. Figure a shows the results on α-2. An increase of χac‘ ‘ was found together with a concomitant decrease of χac‘ on cooling below 22 K, indicating a slow relaxation of the magnetization. χac‘ ‘ exhibited a peak at around 13 K, and the peaking temperature was elevated with an increase of the frequency. According to the Cole−Cole analysis, two humps are found in the plot of χac‘ ‘ vs χac‘ for α-2 (Figure a).
elements.clean_text: To clarify the relaxation behavior, we measured the frequency dependence of χac‘ and χac‘‘, which represent in-phase and out-of-phase parts, respectively, of ac magnetic susceptibility. Figure a shows the results on α-2. An increase of χac‘‘ was found together with a concomitant decrease of χac‘ on cooling below 22 K, indicating a slow relaxation of the magnetization. χac‘‘ exhibited a peak at around 13 K, and the peaking temperature was elevated with an increase of the frequency. According to the Cole-Cole analysis, two humps are found in the plot of χac‘‘ vs χac‘ for α-2 (Figure a).

elements.content: Frequency dependence of χac‘ (top) and χac‘ ‘ (bottom) for (a) α- and (b) β-2 measured on a single crystal.
elements.clean_text: 3  Frequency dependence of χac‘ (top) and χac‘‘ (bottom) for (a) α- and (b) β-2 measured on a single crystal.

elements.content: Cole−Cole diagrams for (a) α- and (b) β-2.
elements.clean_text: 4  Cole-Cole diagrams for (a) α- and (b) β-2.

elements.content: The χac‘ curve of β-2 showed a frequency-independent peak at 11 K and a frequency-dependent shoulder around 6 K (Figure b). The χac‘ ‘ behaved similar to that of α-2, but the peak occurred at a lower temperature. In contrast to the case of α-2, a semicircle is clearly drawn in the Cole−Cole plot for β-2 (Figure b), suggesting that the χac‘ decrease and χac‘ ‘ increase are due to a single relaxation process.
elements.clean_text: The χac‘ curve of β-2 showed a frequency-independent peak at 11 K and a frequency-dependent shoulder around 6 K (Figure b). The χac‘‘ behaved similar to that of α-2, but the peak occurred at a lower temperature. In contrast to the case of α-2, a semicircle is clearly drawn in the Cole-Cole  plot for β-2 (Figure b), suggesting that the χac‘ decrease and χac‘‘ increase are due to a single relaxation process.

elements.content: The relaxation rate (1/τ) is equal to the frequency of the applied ac field (2πν) at the temperature of the maximum of χac‘ ‘. The temperature dependence of τ can be obtained from each χac‘ ‘ curve (Figure (bottom)). The energy barrier (Δ) of the magnetization reorientation could be analyzed based on an Arrhenius-type equation, ln(2πν) = −ln(τ0) − Δ/k B T, giving Δ/k B = 193 K and τ0 = 1.3 × 10-12 s for α-2 and Δ/k B = 71 K and τ0 = 1.1 × 10-10 s for β-2. The Δ value of α-2 was higher than that of 1.
elements.clean_text: The relaxation rate (1/τ) is equal to the frequency of the applied ac field (2πν) at the temperature of the maximum of χac‘‘. The temperature dependence of τ can be obtained from each χac‘‘ curve (Figure  (bottom)). The energy barrier (Δ) of the magnetization reorientation could be analyzed based on an Arrhenius-type equation, ln(2πν) = -ln(τ0) - Δ/k B T, giving Δ/k B = 193 K and τ0 = 1.3 × 10-12 s for α-2 and Δ/k B = 71 K and τ0 = 1.1 × 10-10 s for β-2. The Δ value of α-2 was higher than that of 1.

elements.content: We measured the RM decay as a function of time (Figure S in the Supporting Information). The observed magnetization was expressed as M obs = M SCM exp[−(kt)γ], where the parameter γ has been introduced as a coefficient for the stretched exponential. According to this analysis, the relaxation rate constant k of α-2 was determined and the Arrhenius plot gave the activation energy, Δ‘/k B, calculated to be 162 K with τ0 = 4.8 × 10-9 s. This value does not agree with that of the ac magnetic susceptibility measurements. The reason simply lies in the presence of two relaxation processes, as indicated by the Cole−Cole plot (Figure a); one is operative in the temperature range for the ac measurements (10−15 K) and the other in that for the dc measurements (4−10 K).
elements.clean_text: We measured the RM decay as a function of time (Figure S in the Supporting Information). The observed magnetization was expressed as M obs = M SCM exp[-(kt)γ], where the parameter γ has been introduced as a coefficient for the stretched exponential. According to this analysis, the relaxation rate constant k of α-2 was determined and the Arrhenius plot gave the activation energy, Δ‘/k B, calculated to be 162 K with τ0 = 4.8 × 10-9 s. This value does not agree with that of the ac magnetic susceptibility measurements. The reason simply lies in the presence of two relaxation processes, as indicated by the Cole-Cole plot (Figure a); one is operative in the temperature range for the ac measurements (10-15 K) and the other in that for the dc measurements (4-10 K).

elements.content: Similar analysis from the RM decay on β-2 in a temperature range of 1.8−2.9 K revealed the activation energy to be 61 K (τ0 = 9.3 × 10-9 s). This value seems consistent with that of the ac measurements described above within a possible error due to the narrow temperature range of this experiment.
elements.clean_text: Similar analysis from the RM decay on β-2 in a temperature range of 1.8-2.9 K revealed the activation energy to be 61 K (τ0 = 9.3 × 10-9 s). This value seems consistent with that of the ac measurements described above within a possible error due to the narrow temperature range of this experiment.

elements.content: The magnetization jumps were observed in hysteresis curves, being usually related with quantum tunneling of magnetization. Figure a shows that the jumps took place at H = 0, 0.04, and 0.09 T for α-2 measured at 4.43 K. Detailed differential magnetization plots (Figure S in the Supporting Information) revealed the jumps at 0, 1.1, and 1.8 T for α-2 and 0 and 0.4 T for β-2 at 2.0 K. The position of the steps hardly depended on the temperature between 2.0 and 3.0 K for the former. We measured the hysteresis curves at 2.0 K with the field-sweeping rates of 7.4 × 10-4 and 1.3 × 10-3 T s-1 for the latter and found a very slight shift of the step position. The apparent coercive field (H c) of α-2 at 2 K was 2.0 T, which is much larger than that of 1 (ca. 1 T). On the other hand, β-2 exhibited a narrower hysteresis with H c of 0.25 T at 2 K. This finding implies that α- and β-2 had slower and faster relaxations, respectively, than that of 1, being consistent with the estimation of Δ, though the shape of the hysteresis depends also on the tunneling probability.
elements.clean_text: The magnetization jumps were observed in hysteresis curves, being usually related with quantum tunneling of magnetization. Figure a shows that the jumps took place at H = 0, 0.04, and 0.09 T for α-2 measured at 4.43 K. Detailed differential magnetization plots (Figure S in the Supporting Information) revealed the jumps at 0, 1.1, and 1.8 T for α-2 and 0 and 0.4 T for β-2 at 2.0 K. The position of the steps hardly depended on the temperature between 2.0 and 3.0 K for the former. We measured the hysteresis curves at 2.0 K with the field-sweeping rates of 7.4 × 10-4 and 1.3 × 10-3 T s-1 for the latter and found a very slight shift of the step position. The apparent coercive field (H c) of α-2 at 2 K was 2.0 T, which is much larger than that of 1 (ca. 1 T). On the other hand, β-2 exhibited a narrower hysteresis with H c of 0.25 T at 2 K. This finding implies that α- and β-2 had slower and faster relaxations, respectively, than that of 1, being consistent with the estimation of Δ, though the shape of the hysteresis depends also on the tunneling probability.

elements.content: (a) Differential magnetization curve for a single crystal of α-2 measured at 4.43 K with a constant field-sweeping rate of 1.7 × 10-4 T s-1. Left inset:  field-sweeping sequence. Right inset:  hysteresis curve. (b) Magnetization curves of β-2 measured at 8 and 12 K. Several aligned single crystals were used with a field-sweeping rate of 9.6 × 10-6 T s-1.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Differential magnetization curve for a single crystal of α-2 measured at 4.43 K with a constant field-sweeping rate of 1.7 × 10-4 T s-1. Left inset: field-sweeping sequence. Right inset: hysteresis curve. (b) Magnetization curves of β-2 measured at 8 and 12 K. Several aligned single crystals were used with a field-sweeping rate of 9.6 × 10-6 T s-1.

elements.content: Interestingly, we observed the cusp at 11 K in the χac‘ plot of β-2 (Figure b (top)) and also in the dc FCM measurement (Figure b). We measured magnetization curves with temperature varied around 11 K. An S-shaped curve was clearly drawn in both directions of applying and removing a magnetic field at 8 K, whereas a linear feature was observed at 12 K (Figure b). This finding suggests the presence of a critical point at 11 K for β-2. We suppose a possibility that a metamagnetic-like transition would take place because interchain antiferromagnetic coupling is as small as ca. 0.005 T. However, we could not characterize a ground Néel state below 11 K in the ac/dc magnetic measurements, and no anomaly was found in heat capacity measurements of β-2. Although a possible phase transition could not be eliminated completely, it is most likely that this behavior would originate in the finite-size effects of the 1D Ising system in a paramagnetic phase. The double-peak feature in the χac‘ vs T plot can be described as superposed magnetic properties due to an infinite SCM and precursory fragmental chains.
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, we observed the cusp at 11 K in the χac‘ plot of β-2 (Figure b (top)) and also in the dc FCM measurement (Figure b). We measured magnetization curves with temperature varied around 11 K. An S-shaped curve was clearly drawn in both directions of applying and removing a magnetic field at 8 K, whereas a linear feature was observed at 12 K (Figure b). This finding suggests the presence of a critical point at 11 K for β-2. We suppose a possibility that a metamagnetic-like transition would take place because interchain antiferromagnetic coupling is as small as ca. 0.005 T. However, we could not characterize a ground Néel state below 11 K in the ac/dc magnetic measurements, and no anomaly was found in heat capacity measurements of β-2. Although a possible phase transition could not be eliminated completely, it is most likely that this behavior would originate in the finite-size effects of the 1D Ising system in a paramagnetic phase. The double-peak feature in the χac‘ vs T plot can be described as superposed magnetic properties due to an infinite SCM and precursory fragmental chains.

elements.content: The absence of such an anomaly for α-2 might be due to the structural uniformity in the all-cis chain, whereas the cis,cis,trans mixed configuration of β-2 favors a shorter size of fragmental chains. Further, this structural feature seems responsible for the characteristics of SCMs; α-2 has the higher Δ and longer τ than β-2.
elements.clean_text: The absence of such an anomaly for α-2 might be due to the structural uniformity in the all-cis chain, whereas the cis,cis,trans mixed configuration of β-2 favors a shorter size of fragmental chains. Further, this structural feature seems responsible for the characteristics of SCMs; α-2 has the higher Δ and longer τ than β-2.

elements.content: Metal-radical hybrid magnets such as 3 have often been exploited in pseudo-1D systems. On the other hand, the magnetically discrete 1D structures of 2 behaved as SCMs. In conclusion, the minimal bridging ligand, HNN, is a versatile building block for the development of both bulk magnets and SCMs.
elements.clean_text: Metal-radical hybrid magnets such as 3 have often been exploited in pseudo-1D systems. On the other hand, the magnetically discrete 1D structures of 2 behaved as SCMs. In conclusion, the minimal bridging ligand, HNN, is a versatile building block for the development of both bulk magnets and SCMs.

metadata.title:
Polymorphic Alternating HNN−Cobalt(II) Chains Both Behaving as
Single-Chain Magnets (HNN = 4,4,5,5-Tetramethylimidazolin-1-oxyl
3-Oxide)
